75.text:
From the moment our team was assembled our
initial journey was one of thought and reflection.

81.text:
It culminated in a shared vision for what
this monument must achieve; and this morning,

87.text:
we want to share that vision with you. From
the outset, we concluded that the monument

92.text:
must bring into focus, for a whole new generation,
the meaning of the millions of lives lost

97.text:
in the holocaust, and to do so, we set out
to achieve four central goals.

103.text:
First, to create a meaningful connection to
the Holocaust for all visitors, including

109.text:
those who have no direct link to it or its
victims, opening their hearts and minds to

114.text:
an understanding of the Holocaust for both
its historic specificity and as a universal

121.text:
Next, we wanted to impress upon visitors the
evil of this atrocity so that they examine

128.text:
and confront the dangers of silence and the
consequences of indifference, helping to ensure

134.text:
that its horrors will never be forgotten,
and we wanted to encourage visitors to remember

139.text:
with sensitivity and solemnity the millions
who died and suffered, along with the resilience

145.text:
of the survivors, perpetuating and honouring
their memory among future generations, and

151.text:
finally, we wanted to evoke the lives of those
who perished, celebrating the vitality of

156.text:
the human spirit even in the face of hopelessness
and annihilation.

161.text:
And, because we wanted to open the hearts
and minds of all visitors, the new immigrant

166.text:
to Canada, the family from Lethbridge, the
school group from Montreal, we were determined

173.text:
to create a unique monument that would engage
visitors by creating an overall multi-sensory

179.text:
experience that fuses the best in moving image,
sound, and landscape into a solemn all-embracing

185.text: experience with the widest possible appeal.

the holocaust, and at the same time a symbol

The granite transcendent structure lays heavy

• We see the birch forest and under planting

Europe.

named the death camp Birkenau after the Polish

547.text:
birch trees.
• The birch forest is a symbol of death

551.text:
and horror, a place of hiding and refuge,
and of rebirth and regeneration…and it is

559.text:
a common landscape language that transcends

• The sweep of the curve of the berm directs

structure, and the war museum visible through

• The monument is meant to be celebrated

of the black granite and the white limestone

materials—specifically the granite and limestone,

shrubs, groundcovers, grasses and perennials.

• At the center we have placed a highly

BARTANA FILM
• Yael will create an original multi-channel

705.text:
video that will be motion activated. These
silent images will be projected on the interior

711.text:
wall of the transcendent structure enveloping
the visitor in a highly emotive, entrancing

experience.
• Her innovative work will depict a montage

720.text:
of Holocaust-related objects and images in
a never-ending slow motion free fall, which

726.text:
symbolizes both a loss of control and the
momentous irretrievable loss caused by the

731.text:
Holocaust.
• The slow, beautifully undulating dance

735.text:
of these objects, depicted in high visual
definition, floating down the interior wall,

741.text:
will be arresting and induce solemn contemplation.
• You will now see an early maquette of

747.text:
the work and hear the voice of Yael describing
in her own words, the vision for what will

774.text:
Please take a moment to listen to Yael’s

831.text:
INSCRIPTION
• In the filtered light and shadows of the

837.text:
trees above, just beyond the film, inscribed
on a highly reflective, polished granite surface,

844.text:
the visitor will see the words of Sara Grossman,
a survivor of the Auschwitz, Unterluss and

851.text:
Bergen-Belsen, “…. when you see the pictures
of the dead bodies, you see just pictures.

858.text:
You don’t see the eyes that talk to you
and beg you for water. You don’t see the

863.text:
mouths quietly trying to say something and
not being able to utter a word.”

869.text:
• These are not the words of a poet, an
author, or a philosopher… Rather, they are

875.text:
the recorded words of a survivor.
• And, yet, they remind visitors, with complete

881.text:
clarity that no matter how powerful an experience
we provide, nothing can make us fully comprehend

890.text:
PHILIPSZ
• At this point in the walkthrough, the

893.text:
visitor will begin to hear the sound created
by Susan Philipsz.

898.text:
• Philipsz has adapted her landmark Study
for Strings, derived from a 1943 orchestral

904.text:
work by Pavel Haas, the incarcerated Jewish
composer that was performed by fellow musician

910.text:
inmates at the Theresienstadt transit camp.
• In this new work, the violin parts have

916.text:
been singled out and will play over eight
speakers as visitors move towards the exit

921.text:
into more openness, with the Peace Tower and
Canada’s Parliament buildings coming into

926.text:
view.
• The work will act as a poetic allegory

929.text:
to survival and as a poignant ode to loss.
Singling out one sound from the entire orchestra

936.text:
will speak directly to the singling out of
a people, the very foundational act that enabled

942.text:
this massive genocide to occur.
• And the reverberation of the sound and

947.text:
moments of silence in the monument will further
highlight its emptiness, a direct reference

952.text:
to the void left by the Holocaust that continues
to be felt.

956.text:
FINAL VIEW
As the visitor leaves the core of the monument

960.text:
they finally get a glimpse of Parliament Hill
in the distance. This is a deliberate act

965.text:
on our part and is symbolic of the journey
of the lucky few who survived the holocaust

971.text:
and made it to the safety of Canada, where
three generations later they have prospered

977.text:
and contributed greatly to the peace and prosperity
of Canada and the world.

Help them! Tell everyone the real truth, let

• These words are also from an ordinary
man and will remind the contemporary visitor

1050.text:
why this monument has been built, to let Canadians

played by Canada when our country closed its
eyes and its doors to the real truth faced

CONCLUSION
Time is the enemy of memory. As the events

1135.text:
of the holocaust fade into history and the
last of the survivors are lost to us, the

1140.text:
challenge of how to bridge the gap between
first-hand experience, abstract understanding,

1147.text:
and lack of awareness grows dramatically.
The Canadian National Holocaust Monument must

1157.text:
As you have seen, our design bridges the gap
between those who know and those who may not,

1163.text:
between knowledge of history and the unknowable
experience of the holocaust, between visual

1169.text:
images and the unimaginable, and between the
awareness of evil and the need to act against

1178.text:
Our multisensory experience creates a connection
for all visitors. We use the sculpted forms

1184.text:
as metaphors for the landscapes of Europe
and Canada—but we also use them to celebrate

1190.text:
the indomitable spirit of the victims and
the survivors. We both mourn and celebrate,

1198.text:
and offer the visitor an opportunity to learn
and to empathize…. So as not to forget—So

1208.text:
This Canadian National Holocaust Monument
will forever stand as a unique urban space

1213.text:
in our nation’s capital which conveys powerful
messages about the holocaust, the consequences

1219.text:
of indifference and the enduring strength
of mankind. Thank you. Merci.
